subject: Re: [junit] How to test a method that logs to a file
msgSnippet: Logging is usually not a dependency.  It s not *required* for the object s functionality.  It s merely a *notification* about what the object is doing. --Nat
messageBody:
Logging is usually not a dependency. It's not *required* for the object's
functionality. It's merely a *notification* about what the object is doing.

--Nat

On 07/11/2007, Stephen Smith <steve@...> wrote:
>
> Use the Dependency Injection pattern to inject your Logger into your
> class, and then use JMock or a similar mocking API
> to assert that the logger is called with your expected parameters.
>
> ---
> Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
>
> Nat Pryce wrote:
> >
> >
> > I prefer to separate the notification of significant events from the
> logging
> > (or other handling) of those events. It's easy to test the notification
> > with mock objects and then wire the notifications into a logging system
> in
> > the production system.
> >
> > More info about doing this (in C#) at
> > http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000488.html.
> > <http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000488.html.>
> > And an easy way to implement notifications in Java at
> > http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000710.html.
> > <http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000710.html.>
> >
> > --Nat
> >
